    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-136515-_4lt92rr5muov"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>We investigated 19 new top-level domains (TLDs) released in the past year, which revealed large-scale phishing campaigns, distribution of potentially unwanted programs, torrenting websites, and even pranking and meme campaigns.</p>
<p>We saw correlation between the new TLDs' general availability dates and their popularity, showing that different groups follow the launch of new TLDs and their lifecycle. They do so to initiate domain registration and usage, including for abuse.</p>
<p>There are currently over 1,000 generic top-level domains (TLDs) according to the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) root database, and more new TLDs are being added every year. As new TLDs emerge, the potential for malicious activity such as domain squatting and phishing increases tremendously. This is especially problematic when these TLDs resemble the extensions of popular file extensions such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip,</span> and distinctive service identifiers such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span>.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Network Security</a> solutions, such as <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> subscription services.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/malicious-domains/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Malicious Domains</b></a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/newly-registered-domain" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Newly Registered Domain</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_od3dyzfzof9"></a><strong>New TLDs</strong></h2>
<p>The IANA root database currently lists over 1,000 generic <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/top-level-domains-cybercrime/#post-120952-_llw0ll6i3hu3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">top-level domains</a> (TLDs), with new additions continually being made each year. New TLDs under the <a href="https://icannwiki.org/Generic_top-level_domain" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Generic TLD</a> (gTLD) category are added for myriad reasons including promoting new markets, allowing brands to diversify their web presence, and increasing consumer and business choices.</p>
<p>In the past year and a half, 19 new TLDs have been announced. As more new TLDs are released, companies and other entities may have a hard time keeping up and defensively registering their names on all of them. This presents a possibility for attackers to exploit these TLDs, especially those that resemble file extensions, repurposing them for malicious activities.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_g7nj7evx7544"></a><strong>TLD Rollout Phases</strong></h2>
<p>To understand the potential negative effects of these new TLDs and domain registrations, we first need to understand how new TLDs are rolled out.</p>
<p>All domains under a TLD are tracked in an authoritative database called a <a href="https://www.icann.org/en/icann-acronyms-and-terms/registry-en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">registry</a>. A <a href="https://www.icann.org/en/icann-acronyms-and-terms/registry-operator-en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">registry operator</a> is the organization that maintains this authoritative database of all domain names for a particular TLD.</p>
<p>After new TLDs are delegated and approved for future release, the registry operator associated with the new TLD takes responsibility for the different launch and registration phases. A typical set of launch phases will include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://icannwiki.org/Sunrise_Period" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sunrise</a></li>
<li><a href="https://icannwiki.org/Landrush_Period" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Landrush</a></li>
<li><a href="https://icannwiki.org/Early_Access_Program" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Early access</a></li>
<li><a href="https://icannwiki.org/General_Availability" target="_blank" rel="noopener">General availability</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Note that while these phases are typically associated with generic TLDs, only the sunrise period and general availability are mandatory.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_adv2kxb038ho"></a><strong>Sunrise Period</strong></h3>
<p>This is a mandatory phase for all registries. In this phase, registrations are open only to holders of a validated trademark record in the <a href="https://www.trademark-clearinghouse.com/content/what-trademark-clearinghouse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trademark Clearinghouse</a> (TMCH). This is an effort to help entities secure domain names under new TLDs that fall under their trademark to protect them from cybersquatting and domain squatting attacks <a href="https://icannwiki.org/Sunrise_Period" target="_blank" rel="noopener">according to ICANN Wiki</a>. If more than one entity proves claims to a certain domain, an auction is conducted.</p>
<p>There are two types of sunrise periods:</p>
<ul>
<li>End date sunrise (minimum 60-day length)</li>
<li>The less common Start date sunrise (30-day notice before the start of sunrise period and 30-day minimum length)</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_cmtd9385ga4f"></a><strong>Landrush</strong></h3>
<p>The landrush phase allows registry operators to make registrations open to the public for specific, premium domain names at a higher cost than their price during general availability. Multiple parties applying for the same domain may lead to an auction.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_z581ajkshdxe"></a><strong>Early Access Period/Program</strong></h3>
<p>Certain TLDs also have an early access period that lasts about a week. Some registry operators may not differentiate between the landrush and early access periods (EAP), and others may offer EAP-like pricing during the first week of general availability.</p>
<p>During the EAP, registrants have the opportunity to register a domain name at a premium price before the TLD's official launch during the general availability period on a first-come, first-served basis. The registry operator may set a premium price that is determined based on the number of days starting from the beginning of this period. The first day of early access has the highest registration price and the last day has the lowest, but both are still higher than the general availability period price.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_g7yap8o4l8de"></a><strong>General Availability</strong></h3>
<p>Finally, the TLD is officially launched and moves to a general availability phase where domains under this TLD are available to the public for registration. As mentioned before, some registry operators may offer EAP-like pricing during the first weeks of general availability where domains can be registered for a premium price that slowly drops throughout this period. Typically, a trademark claims phase is in effect in the first 90 days of the general availability period where trademark holders could be alerted when someone registers a domain name matching their trademark.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_l6f2oznq2x8i"></a><strong>Data Sources</strong></h2>
<p>We track the release of new TLDs through <a href="https://www.icann.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the official ICANN website</a>, which reports the sunrise dates for all generic TLDs.</p>
<p>In particular, we are focusing on 19 TLDs that have been released or are in the process of reaching general availability:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.box</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.case</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.channel</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.dad</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.esq</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.foo</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.ing</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lifestyle</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.living</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.meme</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.music</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.nexus</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.phd</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.prof</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.vana</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.watches</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span></li>
</ul>
<p>In April 2024, we gathered data about domains under these TLDs from a variety of sources: <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/connecting-the-dots-in-cyber-threat-campaigns-part-2-passive-dns" target="_blank" rel="noopener">passive DNS</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zone_file" target="_blank" rel="noopener">zone file</a> data published by registry operators, historical <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/newly-registered-domains-malicious-abuse-by-bad-actors/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">newly registered domains</a> (NRDs) and historical <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cybersquatting/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">domain squatting detections</a> in these TLDs. Finally, we augment this list by taking the top 1 million most popular domains on the internet using the <a href="https://tranco-list.eu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tranco</a> list—a research-oriented top site ranking. We replace their TLD with each of the 19 new TLDs in an effort to cover all potential cases of abuse of the most popular domain names.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_j7hro2pcqgz2"></a><strong>Traffic Toward Domains in These New TLDs</strong></h2>
<p>From our customer data logs, Table 1 shows the most-popular new TLDs with the number of unique registered (root) domains.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><b>TLD</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 79.4915%;"><b>Number of Registered Domains</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span></td>
<td style="width: 79.4915%; text-align: center;">5,470</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.ing</span></td>
<td style="width: 79.4915%; text-align: center;">5,071</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span></td>
<td style="width: 79.4915%; text-align: center;">4,179</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span></td>
<td style="width: 79.4915%; text-align: center;">1,279</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 19.1525%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.meme</span></td>
<td style="width: 79.4915%; text-align: center;">1,175</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 1. Most popular TLDs from our customer data logs.</p>
<p>We sampled our traffic logs two times a month and added some important dates from the TLD launch schedule as displayed below in Figure 1. This data indicates that the rise in popularity of the top 10 TLDs correlates with the date that a TLD enters the general availability phase.</p>
<p>The .zip TLD entered general availability on May 10, 2023. From the data on May 16, 2023, we see the first spike in the popularity of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> domains.</p>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.ing</span> TLD entered general availability on Dec. 5, 2023. On that same day we saw a large spike in traffic toward <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.ing</span> domains that has continued since then.</p>
<p>Similarly, Amazon initially allowed registration of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> domains to customers <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/new-bot-gtld-from-amazon/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">exclusively for bot-related services</a>. After the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> TLD entered general availability on Oct. 30, 2023, our data reveals notable increases in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> domain registrations starting on Nov. 1.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136519" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136519" style="width: 1303px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136519" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-935275-136515-1.png" alt="A line graph displaying the growth of internet top-level domains (TLDs) over time, including .bot, .box, .dad, .foo, .mov, .nexus, .zip, .esq, .meme, .img. The graph uses different colors to represent each domain, showing a trend of increasing numbers from left to right along a timeline from May 1, 2023 to April 1, 2024. " width="1303" height="525" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-935275-136515-1.png 1303w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-935275-136515-1-786x317.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-935275-136515-1-768x309.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1303px) 100vw, 1303px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136519" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Popularity of the top 10 new TLDs at different points over the past year from our logs.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The evident correlation between these new TLDs' availability and the number of domain registrations indicates that various groups or individuals closely follow the launch of new TLDs to register new domains. These groups could include adversaries that plan to abuse domains belonging to these newly available TLDs. Therefore, tracking and conducting security checks for domains under emerging TLDs is crucial.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_y46atmgjiy13"></a><strong>Introducing Our Graph-Based Detection System</strong></h2>
<p>Our graph-based detection system is enabled by a powerful internal graph database that ingests comprehensive cybersecurity data from various data sources including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/connecting-the-dots-in-cyber-threat-campaigns-part-2-passive-dns" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Passive DNS data</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/connecting-the-dots-in-cyber-threat-campaigns-part-1-domain-name-whois-information/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WHOIS</a></li>
<li>Third-party threat intelligence sources</li>
<li>Static and dynamic analysis of malware samples</li>
<li>Active web crawl data</li>
</ul>
<p>Leveraging these data sources, we developed a graph-based automated detection system depicted in Figure 2. Starting with a seed list of domains, the system extracts all related data, including associated URLs, IPs and malware samples.</p>
<p>The system generates an independent graph visualization for each seed domain that depicts the relevant relationships with these other associated entities. In this case, the seed list was a list of all domains under these 19 TLDs that we obtained by analyzing information from our previously mentioned data sources.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136521" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136521" style="width: 676px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136521" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-938074-136515-2.png" alt="Flowchart depicting the process of threat intelligence using a graph database. Starts with 'List of Domains' connecting to 'All associated data', which feeds into a graph database represented by clusters of connected nodes. This leads to 'Potential Attack Campaigns' after 'Multi-stage Pruning and Clustering'. Key symbols include a globe icon for the internet, a cloud for data storage, and various connected nodes representing independent graphs and data interactions." width="676" height="441" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-938074-136515-2.png 676w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-938074-136515-2-674x440.png 674w" sizes="(max-width: 676px) 100vw, 676px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136521" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Graph-based detection system design.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After constructing the graph relations, we conduct a multi-stage pruning and graph clustering process. In this process, our system’s pruning algorithm significantly reduces noise and redundancies, only retaining the salient graph paths.</p>
<p>For instance, if a domain uses a globally popular nameserver, then hundreds or thousands of other domains will also use the same nameserver. This results in extra noise added to the graph due to that nameserver node. To address this problem, we prune all paths that are connected to a list of known, benign and popular nodes.</p>
<p>Next, we put these pruned graphs through a clustering process that hunts for commonalities. Our system can cluster domain graphs together based on specific features such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Related IP addresses</li>
<li>Authoritative name servers</li>
<li>Their WHOIS information</li>
<li>Domain name lexical patterns</li>
<li>Traffic and redirection patterns</li>
<li>TLS certificate information</li>
<li>Shared or common web infrastructure and content</li>
</ul>
<p>This process helps us correlate campaigns that share the following traits:</p>
<ul>
<li>The same infrastructure</li>
<li>The same traffic distribution systems</li>
<li>Downloading and disseminating the same malware samples</li>
<li>Abusing a common set of intermediary services to broaden their attacks</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_a77dmyxe52lw"></a><strong>Results: Case Studies</strong></h2>
<p>In this section, we present select network abuse campaigns captured by our graph-based detection system. The results include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Large-scale phishing attacks</li>
<li>Distribution of potentially unwanted programs</li>
<li>Torrenting websites</li>
<li>Pranking or meme campaigns</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_yh8iqww1los5"></a><strong>Redirection Campaign</strong></h3>
<p>Bad actors can leverage trending TLDs and domain names to propagate phishing and redirection attacks. In one such case study, we found that 112 domains belonging to these new TLDs form a tightly related cluster that can be associated with a phishing campaign.</p>
<p>Below, Figure 3 shows the clustered graph for this campaign. The nodes near the middle highlighted in yellow are domains under the newly released TLDs. The red nodes are known malicious indicators that our detectors have already blocked for other suspicious activity or content.</p>
<p>Each blue node represents a relationship between two entities, such as URLs, hostnames, IP addresses and files. Figure 3 reflects four distinct types of relationships in the graph:</p>
<ul>
<li>NS records for the domain</li>
<li>A records for the domain</li>
<li>Redirect to a URL</li>
<li>URLs sharing a “path of” relationship with their root domain</li>
</ul>
<p>At the time of our data collection, all 112 domains redirected to different URL paths under the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]xyz</span> domain.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136523" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136523" style="width: 1299px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136523 size-large" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3-1299x700.png" alt="Network diagram featuring three clusters of nodes connected with lines, indicating relationships among various internet entities including URLs, file samples, hostnames, and IP addresses. The left cluster is colored red, signifying malicious entities, the central cluster is orange, and the right cluster is blue, with each cluster labeled accordingly. A legend explains the color coding and symbols representing different data types and relationships." width="1299" height="700" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3-1299x700.png 1299w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3-786x424.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3-768x414.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3-1536x828.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-940694-136515-3.png 1917w" sizes="(max-width: 1299px) 100vw, 1299px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136523" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Redirection campaign with 112 domains from 11 different newly released TLDs.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Although active as recently as April 2024, by May 2024, this traffic coordination domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]xyz</span> was inactive and returned an NXDOMAIN DNS error. Checking our archived scans and web archive data, we find that these paths had redirected users to a gambling website.</p>
<p>We found these 112 domains subsequently redirected to URL paths under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]click/vx/&lt;string&gt;</span> that redirected to gambling websites. Figure 4 shows an example of one of the gambling pages.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136525" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136525" style="width: 1362px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136525 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-949140-136515-4.png" alt="Screenshot of JoyCasino website homepage featuring a registration form to the left and promotional offers including &quot;WELCOME BONUS UP TO 900%&quot; and &quot;50 FREE SPINS UPON REGISTRATION&quot; displayed on the right side. The background is predominantly purple with decorative golden elements and a spinning roulette wheel image." width="1362" height="731" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-949140-136515-4.png 1362w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-949140-136515-4-786x422.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-949140-136515-4-1304x700.png 1304w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-949140-136515-4-768x412.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1362px) 100vw, 1362px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136525" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Example of a gambling page from this campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<p>All 112 domains share the same four nameservers that are denoted by the nodes on the far right in Figure 3. These nameservers are hosted on the same set of IP addresses, indicating a shared infrastructure.</p>
<p>All 112 domains were also registered with the same registrar, with most registered from June-November 2023. We are the first to detect and block over 78% of these 112 domains according to data from open threat intelligence platforms.</p>
<p>Data from this campaign indicates the group behind it has expanded beyond leveraging newly released TLDs. Our analysis also reveals targeted keywords surrounding recent events. For example, we found at least four new domains relating to the 2024 Summer Olympics are connected to this same campaign.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_z45f7rxxg60s"></a><strong>Chat Bot Service Campaign</strong></h3>
<p>Another cluster involved luring victims into scanning a QR code that redirects them to begin texting over SMS. The SMS session can potentially expose the victim to scams, spam, data harvesting campaigns and exposure of personal information.</p>
<p>Shown in Figure 5, this campaign contains 92 different domains belonging to the .bot TLD. The domains in this cluster have distinct naming patterns. They are either:</p>
<ul>
<li>A person’s first name (such as Akira, Emilia, Mei, Percy or Valentina)</li>
<li>The name of a city (such as Amsterdam, Leipzig or Toronto)</li>
<li>Random German words (such as Fluege, Kleinanzeigen, Termin or Welt)</li>
<li>Random English words (such as Broadband, Chicken or LastMinute)</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_136527" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136527" style="width: 1915px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136527" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5.png" alt="Illustration showing a network of connections between different cybersecurity elements such as URLs, file samples, hostnames, IP addresses, and domain names with a seed list. Red connections indicate malicious entities. A flowchart explains how these elements are related, such as redirecting, subdomain creation, and IP resolution." width="1915" height="772" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5.png 1915w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5-786x317.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5-1736x700.png 1736w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5-768x310.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-953509-136515-5-1536x619.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1915px) 100vw, 1915px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136527" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Homogeneous <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> cluster relating to a chat service campaign with 92 domains.</figcaption></figure>
<p>All of these <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> domains redirected victims to a URL under a different domain ending with the same root name string suffixed by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.php</span>.</p>
<p>For example, the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">harriet[.]bot</span> redirected to the URL at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">phpstack-1171166-4096956.cloudwaysapps[.]com/harriet.php</span></p>
<p>Figure 6 illustrates how the picture/avatar displayed and the QR code changes in relation to the domain name queried.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_136548" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136548" style="width: 786px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136548 size-medium" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6-786x400.jpg" alt="Two promotional digital artworks displayed on computer screens. On the left, an illustration of a character named Harriet Bot, depicted with flowing hair and wearing a dark pullover, a tie and glasses. On the right, an image of a character named Chicken Bot, styled as a rooster and set against a rural backdrop. Some information is redacted.  " width="786" height="400" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6-786x400.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6-1375x700.jpg 1375w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6-768x391.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6-1536x782.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/F6.jpg 1999w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136548" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Two different landing pages under the same domain for URLs ending in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">harriet[.]php</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chicken[.]php</span>.</figcaption></figure>Similar to the previous campaign, all 92 domains share three nameservers hosted on the same IP address. All 92 domains were registered with the same registrar. Notably, all 92 domains were all registered within a two-week period between Nov. 11, 2023, and Dec. 3, 2023, all within five weeks of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bot</span> domain entering general availability.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_qcha7ghmdr7i"></a><strong>Torrenting Unblockit Cluster</strong></h3>
<p>Investigating homogeneous clusters, we found a campaign distributing pirating and torrenting links that contain four domains using the same root name with four different TLDs:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.esq</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.ing</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.foo.</span></li>
</ul>
<p>URLs under these domains all have similar paths as well.</p>
<p>Our graph-based analysis reveals that the infrastructure of these torrenting services keeps evolving as its domains are blocked by security vendors. Figure 7 indicates URL paths that redirect users to the same path under a different TLD, possibly as a mirroring phenomenon.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136531" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136531" style="width: 1913px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136531 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7.png" alt="Diagram showing a network of cybersecurity threats with various types of connections like redirects and subdomains between entities. Red indicates malicious entities. Includes URLS, file samples, hostnames, IP addresses with geolocation, and domains. Key symbols and relationship types are explained in a legend at the bottom." width="1913" height="1082" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7.png 1913w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7-778x440.png 778w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7-1238x700.png 1238w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7-768x434.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-962836-136515-7-1536x869.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1913px) 100vw, 1913px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136531" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The unblockit torrenting campaign that highlights the evolving infrastructure.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Following this pattern, we found websites with the root name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unblockit</span> under different TLDs. We found 11 additional domains that all redirected to the same <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unblockit</span> torrenting webpage.</p>
<p>Similar to the above cluster, we found another campaign that uses the root name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">worldfree4u</span> with different TLDs, which is a torrent and piracy distribution website. Figure 8 shows that we observed the same domain name under five different TLDs:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.foo</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.meme</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.dad</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 8 reflects a serial chain of redirections of URLs from one domain under one TLD to another.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136533" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136533" style="width: 1912px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136533" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8.png" alt="Network diagram showing various connections between entities such as URLs, IP addresses, and domain names, with some entities marked in red indicating malicious status. Arrows describe relationships, such as redirection or subdomains. The diagram includes descriptive legends like URL, File/Sample Hash, Hostname, IP address, and Domain in seed list." width="1912" height="1306" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8.png 1912w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8-644x440.png 644w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8-1025x700.png 1025w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8-768x525.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-967611-136515-8-1536x1049.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1912px) 100vw, 1912px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136533" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Charting the worldfree4u campaign distributing piracy and torrent links.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_tfaqclmglpo2"></a><strong>Examining Previously Reported Malicious TLDs and Domains</strong></h2>
<p>Of all the newly released TLDs, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span> are two TLDs that are among the 10 most popular that also resemble popular file extensions. When Google released these two TLDs for general availability in May 2023, many sources commented on the dangers of these TLDs and how attackers were already leveraging them to perpetuate phishing attacks. Consequently, many of these domains were blocked by security vendors, and new domains under these TLDs began to be scrutinized more carefully.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_7ie4dj3okk20"></a><strong>Malware, Critiques and Pranks</strong></h3>
<p>We analyzed previously reported malicious <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> domains and found they have either become NXDOMAINs, parked pages or result in network traffic errors. Some of these previously malicious domains redirect to pages critiquing the TLD, like <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">latestupdate[.]zip</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">googlechrome[.]zip</span>. Figure 9 illustrates an example of the critique sites.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136535" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136535" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136535" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-972508-136515-9-1161x700.jpeg" alt="Screenshot of a browser on a web page displaying the text, &quot;really? who thought .zip was a good idea&quot;, followed by a facepalm emoji." width="700" height="422" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-972508-136515-9-1161x700.jpeg 1161w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-972508-136515-9-730x440.jpeg 730w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-972508-136515-9-768x463.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-972508-136515-9.jpeg 1475w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136535" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Example of a previously malicious domain hosting criticism about the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> TLD.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Websites from domains using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> TLD can automatically offer ZIP archives for download. These ZIP archives can contain anything, depending on who established the web server.</p>
<p>Some domains previously reported as malicious now contain prank content. For instance, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">assignment[.]zip</span> downloads a ZIP archive that contains a picture of a leek and one music track (mp3 file), while <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">photos[.]zip</span> simply contains the text: “haha you got phished!”</p>
<p>At least two servers using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> TLD domains previously reported as malicious currently distribute content flagged as malware. The first is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eicar-test-file[.]zip</span> that appears to send a randomly named ZIP archive containing an EICAR test file.</p>
<p>The second is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bomb[.]zip</span>, a site that critiques ICANN's decision to approve the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> TLD. It states "We heard you like zip bombs!" and sends a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zip_bomb" target="_blank" rel="noopener">zip bomb</a>.</p>
<p>From our studies, we see that many <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span> domains are being used for pranks and memes such as rickrolling.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136515-_vwjvwmya7qbs"></a><strong>Leveraging TLDs That Look Like File Extensions for Trolling</strong></h3>
<p>We also observe that domains, specifically ones that appear to be file extensions, are <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ" target="_blank"  rel="wpdevart_lightbox_video noopener" >increasingly used for trolling online</a>. Specifically for <a href="https://www.dictionary.com/e/slang/rickrolling/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">rickrolling</a>, we observed 13 domains in this cluster under the TLDs <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.mov</span> redirected users to a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bit[.]ly</span> link that led to a YouTube music video of a 1987 song titled “Never Gonna Give You Up” by musician Rick Astley.</p>
<p>These 13 domains resemble file names such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attachedpdf[.]zip</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">testvideo[.]mov</span>. All of them point to the same set of nameservers denoted by the node on the left in Figure 10. They also have the same four IP addresses in their A record, indicated on the right in Figure 10.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136537" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136537" style="width: 1912px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136537" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10.png" alt="Illustration of a network showing the interaction between various internet elements and an entity identified as malicious, indicated by red. The graphic includes symbols like WWW, user icons, and flags, symbolizing interactions such as redirection and domain resolutions in a web context." width="1912" height="1086" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10.png 1912w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10-775x440.png 775w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10-1232x700.png 1232w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10-768x436.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/word-image-975372-136515-10-1536x872.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1912px) 100vw, 1912px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136537" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Cluster that points to a link-shortener link that redirects users to get rickrolled.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_pqu1jr8i1rsp"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>We investigated domains registered under 19 newly released TLDs from the past year. To sustainably track the evolution of these domains over time, we introduced our graph-based investigation pipeline that can help identify coordinated attack and misuse campaigns.</p>
<p>This article presented detailed case studies on a variety of cyberthreats to show how domains registered on these newly released TLDs have been used for redirection, chatbot campaigns and torrent distribution. As new TLDs emerge, the potential for malicious activity such as domain squatting and phishing increases. This investigation reveals the importance of monitoring domains registered under new TLDs to discover and track new trends and attack campaigns.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers receive protections against malicious indicators (domain, IP address) mentioned in this article via <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security">Advanced DNS Security</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> subscription services.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136515-_bswgoqa7u121"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<p>The following are domains and URL paths related to this article.</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">akira[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">amsterdam[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attachedpdf[.]zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">broadband[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chicken[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]click</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]click/vx/</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">choto[.]xyz</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">crowdstrike-hotfix[.]zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">crowdstrikefix[.]zip</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">emilia[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fluege[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">harriet[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kleinanzeigen[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lastminute[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">leipzig[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mei[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">percy[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">phpstack-1171166-4096956.cloudwaysapps[.]com/chicken.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">phpstack-1171166-4096956.cloudwaysapps[.]com/harriet.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">termin[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">testvideo[.]mov</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">toronto[.]bot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unblockit[.]black</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unblockit[.]esq</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unblockit[.]ing</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">worldfree4u[.]dad</span></li>

</ul>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 30 August, 2024 at 6:41 AM PDT</span>-->

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital representation of a networked globe centered on South America, surrounded by glowing nodes connected by lines, symbolizing global connectivity and information technology." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_DNS_Overview_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tracking-newly-released-top-level-domains:related-resources:Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-tunneling-in-the-wild/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tracking-newly-released-top-level-domains:related-resources:Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cobalt-strike/" title="Cobalt Strike" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tracking-newly-released-top-level-domains:related-resources:Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild:Cobalt Strike">Cobalt Strike</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/decoy-dog-malware/" title="Decoy Dog malware" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tracking-newly-released-top-level-domains:related-resources:Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild:Decoy Dog malware">Decoy Dog malware</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dns-tunneling/" title="DNS tunneling" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tracking-newly-released-top-level-domains:related-resources:Understanding DNS Tunneling Traffic in the Wild:DNS tunneling">DNS tunneling</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</html>
